awd_titl_txt: A Model Study of the Impact of Volcanic Eruptions on Polar Ozone Depletion.
awd_abstract_narration:
Gases and aerosols from volcanic eruptions cause changes in the ozone chemistry and energy balance of the upper atmosphere. This study will investigate the how past volcanic eruptions have influenced polar stratospheric clouds and stratospheric ozone.  The project will also compare the effect of smaller, sustained volcanic emissions to the effect of large eruptions.  A computer model of atmospheric chemistry, dynamics, and radiation will be used to examine the impact of past eruptions and how they may slow down the recovery of the ozone hole. This study will also improve the models by including more realistic polar stratospheric clouds, which will improve our ability to model atmospheric chemistry, and ultimately, climate.

This study will investigate the evolution of polar stratospheric clouds (PSCs) influenced by volcanic eruptions and the resulting effect on ozone and related chemicals. Volcanic aerosols are observed to change stratospheric radiative flux and chemistry. Ozonesonde and satellite observations show enhanced ozone loss in the mid-latitudes and over Antarctica following the Mr. Pinaubo, Cerro Hudson, and El Chichon erruptions. An unanswered question is how small erruptions which occur every year but only inject a small fraction of the sulfur as a large eruption impact the ozone loss in polar regions and slow down the recovery of the ozone hole. This study will use the NSF/NCAR Whole Atmosphere Community Climate Model (WACCM) with detailed ozone chemistry and the Community Aerosol and Radiation Model for Atmospheres (CARMA) with an interactive sulfate and PSCs model. The model experiments will inject SO2 into the atmosphere in different amounts, times, and locations to simulate the volcanic eruptions observed during the past few decades. The results will be compared to satellite and in-situ observations from microphysical scales to global scales. Another goal of the project is to improve the NSF/NCAR WACCM model by treating PSCs more realistically. The project is relevant to understanding how the deposition of sulfates and dust in ice cores relates to the locations and strength of eruptions, to understanding year-to-year variations in Antarctic ozone loss driven by small eruptions, and to understanding the effect of PSCs and volcanic aerosols on the Antarctic energy balance.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
This project investigates the role of volcanic eruptions on Antarctic ozone depletion, stratospheric aerosol features, and stratospheric chemistry. Our research contributes knowledge related to the Montreal Protocol and increases our confidence in the Antarctic ozone depletion and recovery theory. Our research also reveals important stratospheric volcanic chemical processes that have been ignored in current climate model predictions. Under this grant, we published two peer-reviewed papers and have two under review. Zhu et al. (2017) show we've developed and validated a full polar stratospheric cloud (PSC) model in a global climate model framework. It is the first global model in the U.S. that includes the microphysical formation of sulfate and the three main types of PSCs. Zhu et al. (2018) simulated the aerosols after the 2015 Mt. Calbuco eruption and confirmed the impact of volcanic aerosol on polar ozone depletion, which is a big part of the ozone recovery theory. Zhu et al. (2020) simulated the volcanic ash and SO2 evolution after the 2014 Mt. Kelut eruption. We found the volcanic ash has a potential impact on global climate chemistry and radiation. We found that the ash is lighter, larger, and lasts longer than in current simulations conducted by the climate community. We also found the simulated SO2 lifetime was about three times longer than observed, indicating an error in the modeled SO2 chemistry. Clyne et al. (2020) compared the volcanic aerosol simulations among several state-of-the-art global climate models. We found the neglect the computation of OH interactively by some models caused major inter-model differences in aerosol optical depth prediction, and differences in computed particle radius were one of the biggest reasons.

Our work enhances the United States' infrastructure for climate research. We are creating new capabilities in the NSF/DOE/NCAR Community Earth System Model (CESM) to more accurately represent volcanic clouds, PSCs, and their interactions. Our model is the only sectional model in the U.S. that deals with the microphysical formations of major stratospheric aerosols and PSCs. Therefore, our model simulations have identified possible improvements and provided useful aerosol and cloud parameters for other current state-of-the-art models that use simpler, but computationally more efficient, aerosol schemes (Zhu et al., 2017). The released version of our model is on the shared trunk of CESM where other researchers can access it, use it, and import it to other codes. For example, researchers at NASA Goddard have imported our version of the sectional volcanic model to the GEOS-5 model where they plan to use it for satellite data retrieval.

Our datasets have supported and will support several field campaigns and climate simulation experiments. These projects include the following: Yu et al.’s wildfire smoke in the stratosphere project, in 2018-2019, an interactive stratospheric aerosol model intercomparison project (ISA-MIP), in progress, Deshler et al.’s measurements of stratospheric aerosol to altitudes above 35 km project, in 2019 and 2021, and the Asian summer monsoon chemicals and climate Impact project (ACCLIP), in 2021.

Our work enhances the United States' infrastructure for education and improved STEM education in graduate-level classes. The 1-d version of our cloud model was used in the University of Colorado Atmospheric and Oceanic Science graduate class "Numerical Modeling of Clouds and Aerosols” taught by Professor Toon in 2018. In that class, students explored ways to simulate various processes in the cloud and aerosol physics. We’ve developed a research-grade code that is simple enough for undergraduates to use on a PC to produce graphical output yet complex enough for graduate student to use in their experiments. We simplified and improved the visualization of the model output for all students.

This work increases the participation of women in STEM by supporting a female scientist in her early career and supporting a female graduate student in completing her Ph.D. studies. This work increases partnerships between the University of Colorado and other research institutes. Additionally, this project has supported a graduate student and researchers at the University and NCAR scientists to work together to improve the climate model developed at NCAR.

This project increases public scientific literacy and K-12 education on the Montreal protocol, stratospheric ozone depletion and recovery theory, atmospheric aerosols, and general knowledge of space and atmospheric science. The PI presented a public lecture in 2018 at Nanjing University, China, and presented a science seminar in 2018 and assisted public tours in 2019 at the Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics at University of Colorado Boulder.
